citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Total number of vacant residences by Census Tract for the Conterminous United States

pubinfo.publish: U.S. EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract:
This EnviroAtlas dataset portrays the total number of vacant residential addresses for each Census Tract for each year from 2010-2014. Vacant buildings are included if they remained vacant for more than one year. Data were compiled from the United States Postal Service (USPS) Vacant Address Data.
This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas). Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose:
This data layer records the total number of vacant residential addresses for each Census tract. It can be used to study the extent and pattern of vacancies, both locally and for the conterminous US. In addition, researchers from government and private sectors can use this data layer to further investigate causes of local vacancy problems. For instance, this data layer can be used with socioeconomic data to examine whether/how vacancy is associated with socioeconomic factors (e.g. household income level, age, and employment) (Nassauer and Raskin, 2014). Secondly, vacancy data can also be examined together with environmental factors (e.g. land use types, or green space) to see whether there is any interaction between the natural environment and vacancy phenomena. Thirdly, temporal changes of the vacancy rate can be investigated, and causes for temporal changes can also be analyzed.
The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html

procstep.procdesc: Obtained the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)-aggregated USPS Vacant Address Data (https://www.huduser.gov/portal/datasets/usps.html) for the contiguous US.

Vacancy data were analyzed from December 2010 to December 2014 and recorded based on the 2010 Census Tract map. For each year, residential buildings that had been vacant for more than one year were included. The total number of vacant building units within a geographic unit (Census tract) was counted using ArcGIS 10.2 Table Join tool.

overview.eaover: The number of vacant residences was recorded as zero only if the number of vacant building units is zero. If vacancy information is missing, data were recorded as Null.
